title: Round armchair with plastic cords and metal frame
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00410

  Image: 

  object_work_type: armchairs

  title_text: Round armchair with plastic cords and metal frame

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creation_date: 1960s - 1970s

  creation_place_original_location: Malaysia Singapore

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: plastic (organic material) metal

  techniques_name: forming (physical activity) metalworking

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: The image depicts an armchair. It has a round seat shape. Both the seat and the back of the armchair are made out of woven plastic cords. These cords come in a myriad of colours
 from purple to green to red. The frame of the armchair is also painted red
 and the legs are grey in colour.The arms of the armchair contain a flower motif
 with four images of yellow flowers on either side. There does not seem to be any visible cracks on the chair. The paint on the legs of the armchair is slightly chipped and a little rust can be seen.

  subject_terms_1: flower (motif) portable furniture

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Armchairs

  sgcool_label_text: Made in Singapore and Malaysia
 this round armchair with woven plastic cords and a white painted metal frame was iconic in the 1960s and 1970s. The true inspiration for this chair is not known
 but could possibly be influenced by the Scandinavian chairs with plastic/polyurethane cords of the 1950s and 1960s. Users of such armchairs would have enjoyed its cooling effect under the warm climate of Singapore.

metadata.title_text: Round armchair with plastic cords and metal frame
metadata.physical_appearance: The image depicts an armchair. It has a round seat shape. Both the seat and the back of the armchair are made out of woven plastic cords. These cords come in a myriad of colours, from purple to green to red. The frame of the armchair is also painted red, and the legs are grey in colour.The arms of the armchair contain a flower motif, with four images of yellow flowers on either side. There does not seem to be any visible cracks on the chair. The paint on the legs of the armchair is slightly chipped and a little rust can be seen.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Made in Singapore and Malaysia, this round armchair with woven plastic cords and a white painted metal frame was iconic in the 1960s and 1970s. The true inspiration for this chair is not known, but could possibly be influenced by the Scandinavian chairs with plastic/polyurethane cords of the 1950s and 1960s. Users of such armchairs would have enjoyed its cooling effect under the warm climate of Singapore.
